newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Vietnam coffee trade at trickle as stocks dwindle.
newsitem.headline: Vietnam coffee trade at trickle as stocks dwindle.

text.p: Vietnam's robusta coffee market was at a near standstill on Friday as the end of the 1996/97 season approached and as buyers turned towards Indonesia, dealers said.
"Vietnam is running out of coffee," said one trader. "The prices in Indonesia are becoming more attractive and the buyers are shifting away from Vietnam towards Indonesia."
Little activity was reported but traders and merchants said buyers were bidding around $1,300-1,320 per tonne FOB Saigon Port and sellers were looking for prices of up to $1,350-1,370.
"Prices in the outside market are lower than the internal level", a trader said. "...and prices in London are unlikely to go up."

Vietnam has exported an estimated 220,000 tonnes of coffee so far from its 1996/97 crop, which was harvested in October and November. Remaining stocks were estimated at no more than 30,000-40,000 tonnes.
